conclusion: To solve for the mass of block B, analyze the forces acting on block A and block B when they are stationary.
Define T as the tension in the rope, m as the mass of block A, and M as the mass of block B.
Block A is on a smooth slope inclined at 30°.
The forces acting on block A are gravitational force mg downward, normal force perpendicular to the slope, and tension force T up the slope.
Resolve gravitational force into components: parallel to the slope mg sin 30° and perpendicular to the slope mg cos 30°.
For block A to remain stationary, net force along the slope must be zero, so T = mg sin 30°.
For block B, the tension in the rope is the same.
The forces acting on block B are gravitational force Mg downward and tension force T upward.
For block B to remain stationary, net force must be zero, so Mg = T.
Substitute T = mg/2 into the equation for block B: Mg = mg/2.
The mass of block B, M, is m/2.
Final answer: M = (√3/2)m, meaning the mass of block B is √3/2 times the mass of block A.
